awd_abstract_narration:
An operating system is the key software of a computer system that manages the hardware and software resources and provides essential services to computer programs. It plays a critical role in the security of the whole system. Unfortunately, modern operating systems are often bloated with millions of lines of source code, and serious vulnerabilities are routinely being discovered and exploited from them. Researchers have proposed various novel solutions based on the "one-layer-below" approach, in which a more privileged software component (i.e., a hypervisor) is introduced to monitor and/or regulate the operating system?s behavior. However, the large trusted computing base of modern hypervisors and the recent attacks against them put this approach into question. This project aims at developing a systematic approach to  improve the trustworthiness of operating systems by enabling their self-defense, without resorting to other software layers that may be vulnerable themselves.

The goal of this project is being achieved in three key steps: first, the project develops a kernel-level security enclave that will provide a trusted, secure execution environment for other security systems and mechanisms. Second, based on the strong isolation provided by the enclave, the researchers design and implement several self-defense techniques for operating system kernels. Third, a cold-boot attack is a powerful physical attack that can extract sensitive information from the physical memory of a lost or stolen computer (including mobile devices). It has become a major security concern for corporations and governments. This project investigates a comprehensive defense against cold-boot attacks by encrypting the whole memory of a sensitive program on commodity hardware platforms. The results from this project could substantially improve our defensive capabilities against malicious and stealthy kernel-level malware and cold-boot attacks, and thus significantly improving the trustworthiness of computer systems. Research results are disseminated through publications, releasing of the tools developed, and integrating into the educational activities at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.

por.por_cntn:
Modern computer systems have an exceedingly complicated software stack and thus vulnerabilities are inevitable. The main goal of this project is to design a series of systematic approaches to improve the security of computer software systems. 

Over the years, we have built a series of systems to achieve this goal. For example, we built Remix, an on-demand live randomization system that can shuffle the program code around while the program is running, making the program an elusive target for attacks. Another system we built is called origin-sensitive control-flow integrity (OS-CFI). While an unprotect program can be hijacked by attackers to do many malicious things, a program under the protection of OS-CFI runs like a train that can only go where the rails lead to. In addition to retrofitting programs with runtime protections, we also designed and built systems to detect vulnerabilities in programs. For example, we proposed a model for vulnerabilities in the Intel SGX enclave system. SGX is an important security module in Intel systems to provide strong security guarantees to sensitive software. Our system detected more than 50 security bugs in some popular SGX software. 

Many of these systems have been peer-reviewed and published in the top security and systems conferences, such as Usenix Security, ASPLOS (ACM International Conference on Architectural Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems), and Usenix ATC (Annual Technical Conference). In total, we published nine papers, and six of them were in the top-tier conferences. To broadly disseminate the research supported by this award, we released three of the systems, which we spent years building, with liberal open-source licenses. They are available publicly from the syssecfsu account at GitHub (https://github.com/syssecfsu). 

This award also allowed us to support and graduate two PhDs in computer security, Dr. Yue Chen (2018) and Dr. Mustakimur Khandaker (2020). Both students had produced high-quality research. Dr. Chen is currently working as a staff researcher at Palo Alto Networks, the largest cybersecurity company in the US. Dr. Khandaker is currently a tenure-track assistant professor at University of Georgia. The award also partially supported Abu Naser, expecting to receive his PhD degree in 2022. 

This project helped us to improve the education in computer security. At FSU, the PI created a new course, CIS4626/5627 introduction to offensive computer security. It introduces students to identify, exploit, and avoid common software computer vulnerabilities, such as buffer overflows and cross-site request forgery. It has been a popular course among students with about 70 students in Fall 2021. While teaching the course, the PI identified a number of challenges especially under the current circumentence of the COVID-19 pandemic. To address that, the PI built a program called WiTTY (Web-based interactive TTY)  that allows students to easily record, replay, and share their project progress and problems. WiTTY enables instructors to quickly identify and solve students? questions about their projects. WiTTY is open-sourced under the same GitHub account. We believe WiTTY can be broadly adopted because it is useful for any courses that use a UNIX-like shell environment. We also created materials to teach young kids programming. 

Overall, the award has enabled us to improve the security of computer systems and our education efforts in computer security.
